input_prompt:
Extract all factual claims from this YouTube transcript:

What you’re about to see… is a historic moment. [TRUMP]: “...we're very much working very closely with China and president Xi.” [HOST]: Not that. [TRUMP]:”...if you look at Idlib Province in Syria.” [HOST]: Nope [TRUMP]:“So, Prime Minister Abe came here…” [HOST]: Not that either... But this... [TRUMP]: “I'm going to be signing a national emergency. And it's been signed many times before. It's been signed by other presidents. There's rarely been a problem. They sign it; nobody cares. ..” [HOST]: President Trump is right, many other presidents have used this power before. But his declaration isn’t normal. At all. Why? Because by using it to fund his proposed border wall, he has made it the first time a president has used this power to pay for policy that had already been rejected by Congress. [GOITEIN]: “This this is an unprecedented abuse of power in terms of the president basically saying that Congress cannot limit him.” [HOST]: That’s Elizabeth Goitein from the Brennan Center for Justices. She’s extensively studied presidential declarations of National Emergencies. And she’ll help us better understand what’s different about Trump’s declaration. Let's start here, in December 2018: [TRUMP]: “I am proud to shutdown the government for border security, Chuck. … I will take the mantle. I will be the one to shut it down. I’m not going to blame you for it.” [HOST]: Trump said he would refuse to sign a budget into law unless it included $5.7 billion dollars for his proposed border wall on the U.S. / Mexico border. Democrats, who took control of the House of Representatives in January, refused to give in to the president’s demand. The result… a political stalemate and the longest government shutdown in U.S. history. Eventually, on February 14th, a budget was passed… but it did not include funding for the border wall. That’s when Trump decided to take executive action to fund his border wall by declaring a “national emergency.” [GOITEIN]: This president is pushing a very dangerous vision of constitutional government where the president gets to do what he wants. And that's not what the Constitution provides for. This is dangerous. It's undemocratic. [HOST]: The declaration allows the president to unilaterally divert billions of dollars from military construction projects to fund this border wall. But now, Trump’s declaration is being challenged in the courts and Congress. In a historic vote on February 26th, the House of Representatives voted to block a presidential national emergency for the first time ever. The legislation now moves to the Senate. [GOITEIN]: I think it's has a good chance of passing the Senate. At that point of course the president would veto it and then the chances are overriding that veto are slim to be sure. [HOST]: That’s because Congress would need a supermajority vote, two-thirds of both chambers, to override a presidential veto. And since some say it’s unlikely that it will be blocked by Congress, it will be left up to the courts to determine whether it’s legal or not. Right now, 16 states are suing the president for what they say is an “unconstitutional” use of executive power. The lawsuit claims the president has used a “manufactured crisis” to call for an emergency. [GOITEIN]: “In this case it's very clear from the president's words and his actions that he is declaring this emergency for the purpose of getting around Congress… That's an abuse of power. [HOST]: What Goitein is saying there… isn’t really controversial. In fact, the president even made this point himself in the very same speech where he first announced his declaration. [TRUMP]: “I could do the wall over a longer period of time, I didn't need to do this, but I'd rather do it much faster.” [HOST]: But let’s take a step back. Despite this announcement being the first of its kind, presidential declarations of national emergencies definitely aren’t anything new, or out of the ordinary. For example, in addition to this most recent one, President Trump has declared three others during his time in office. President Obama? He issued 12. Bush? 13. And Clinton? 17. In addition to the recent one, there are 31 other active national emergencies, which need to be renewed every year. The oldest one still in effect is from president Jimmy Carter in 1979 -- which were sanctions in response to the Iran hostage crisis. But when did this type of power first arise? First, it’s important to know that the U.S. Constitution doesn’t explicitly give a president the right to declare a national emergency. But presidents have taken this type of unilateral action for some time now -- claiming it’s part of the “executive powers” granted to them in the constitution. President Woodrow Wilson was the first president to declare a national emergency during World War I. Since then, numerous presidents have used this type of executive power -- sometimes in really awful ways. Take Franklin Roosevelt for example… He used it to order the internment of over 100,000 Japanese-Americans during World War II . But this type of executive power has been successfully blocked too. In the 1950s, the Supreme Court blocked President Harry Truman’s attempt to nationalize the steel industry during the the Korean War. With this type of presidential overreach fresh in the minds of Congress, it took action to scale back executive power in the 1970s. [GOITEIN]: “There had been several just massive scandals involving executive branch overreach. For example Watergate, the bombing of Cambodia during Vietnam, the CIA's domestic spying programs and all of these things came to light at around the same time. And so Congress just decided to take a very hard look at executive power in general.” [HOST]: It passed the National Emergencies Act of 1976. The legislation formalized a president’s ability to declare national emergencies, but also aimed to give legislators the ability to check the president’s power. But Goitein says since it passed, the law has failed to limit presidential powers the way it intended to. And she argues that if Trump’s recent declaration is allowed to stay in effect, it would set a really dangerous precedent. [GOITEIN]: It is not by any means the scariest of the emergency powers that become available to a president when he declares a national emergency. There are powers that allow the president simply by declaring a national emergency to shut down or take over radio stations. Powers that allow him to freeze Americans bank accounts and criminalize doing business with Americans that are designated by the government. [HOST]: Those examples of potential areas of abuse by a president are why Goiten says Congress needs to act now -- not only to place limits on President Trump’s power, but for those who occupy the office after him as well.

claims.text: Trump's declaration is the first time a president has used national emergency powers to fund a policy rejected by Congress.
The House of Representatives voted to block a presidential national emergency for the first time ever on February 26th.
16 states are suing the president for what they claim is an unconstitutional use of executive power.
claims.context: Ongoing legal challenges to Trump's national emergency declaration.

claims.text: President Trump has declared three national emergencies during his time in office.
claims.context: Trump's use of national emergency powers.

input_prompt:
Claim:
Trump's declaration is the first time a president has used national emergency powers to fund a policy rejected by Congress.

Article Title:
List of national emergencies in the United States - Wikipedia

Full Page Content:
The 1976 National Emergencies Act implemented various legal requirements regarding emergencies declared by the President of the United States. As of July 2025, ...

Provide relevant evidence.

Claim:
Trump's declaration is the first time a president has used national emergency powers to fund a policy rejected by Congress.

Article Title:
Supreme Court Stays Injunction That Had Blocked a Portion of the ...

Google Search Snippet:
As a result, the court issued a preliminary injunction barring the Administration from using $1 billion in funds transferred under Section 8005 ...

Full Page Content:
Rush a gift toward our critical fund before 12/31 and help push back and win against the Trump administration attacks on civil liberties.
Donations to the ACLU are not tax-deductible.
In February 2019, the ACLU filed a lawsuit challenging President Trump’s emergency powers declaration to secure funds to build a wall along the southern border. The lawsuit was filed on behalf of the Sierra Club and the Southern Border Communities Coalition. The lawsuit argues that the president is usurping Congress’s appropriations power and threatening the clearly defined separation of powers inscribed in the Constitution. On January 20, 2021, President Biden halted further border wall construction. Litigation in this and subsequent related challenges has been paused or deadlines extended while the ACLU’s clients and the Biden administration determine next steps.
By completing this form, I agree to receive occasional emails per the terms of the ACLU's privacy statement.
Although Congress refused to give in to President Trump's demands for a border wall and imposed spending restrictions to protect wildlife areas and the integrity of border communities, President Trump claimed emergency authority to divert billions of dollars that Congress had appropriated for other purposes to build his wall. President Trump, all but admitting that the emergency declaration was not necessary, claimed that he “didn’t need to do this” but wanted to construct a wall “much faster” than Congress was allowing.
Border wall construction as carried out as directed under the Trump emergency declaration harms communities living along the border, endangers wildlife, and has devastating impacts on the environment.
The Southern Border Communities Coalition brings together 60 organizations from California, Arizona, New Mexico, and Texas to promote policies and solutions that improve quality of life in border communities. The hyper-militarization of the border wall, accelerated by President Trump's declaration, has increased anti-immigrant sentiment and marginalized communities of color even further.
The Sierra Club is a national organization with 67 chapters and more than 3.5 million members and supporters dedicated to protecting and restoring the quality of the natural and human environment.
The lawsuit argues that the President Trump's declaration and diversion of funds violate core constitutional principles and multiple laws and statutes, including the 2019 Appropriations Act, the Constitution’s Presentment Clause, and the constitutional principle of separation of powers.
The 2019 Appropriations Act passed by Congress explicitly rejected President Trump’s $5.7 billion demand for a border wall and forbade construction in certain areas, including carve-outs for wildlife areas. Further, the president violated the Presentment Clause by signing the 2019 Appropriations Act but then rejecting it by declaring a national emergency to build more of a border wall than Congress permitted and faster than Congress allowed.
The emergency declaration also violates the National Environmental Policy Act, which requires agencies to conduct environmental assessments and consider the harm to wildlife before proceeding with construction.
The lawsuit was filed in the Northern District of California, and the defendants also include the secretaries of Defense, Homeland Security, and Treasury.
Sierra Club, Southern Border Communities Coalition, and ACLU Reach Settlement with U.S. Government in Border Wall Case Challenging the Illegal Transfer of Military Construction Funds
ACLU, Sierra Club, and SBCC Respond to the Biden Administration’s Request to Delay Border Wall SCOTUS Arguments
Appeals Court Rules Trump’s Border Wall Illegal, Blocks Further Construction
ACLU Comment on Supreme Court Order in Border Wall Challenge
ACLU Takes Border Wall Fight to Supreme Court
Appeals Court Rules Trump’s Border Wall Illegal
Supreme Court Order No ‘Big Victory’ For Trump’s Border Wall. The Fight Continues.
I’ve Lived on the Border My Entire Life. The Courts Must Shut Down Trump’s Border Wall
Trump’s ‘Big, Beautiful’ Wall Crumbles in Court
Trump’s ‘Emergency’ Declaration Is Illegal
There Is No ‘National Emergency’ at the Border, and Trump’s Declaration Is Illegal
© 2025 American Civil Liberties Union

Provide relevant evidence.

output.summary: The evidence indicates that President Trump's declaration of a national emergency to fund the border wall was indeed the first time a president used such powers to fund a policy that Congress had explicitly rejected, as Congress had denied his request for $5.7 billion for the wall in the 2019 Appropriations Act.
output.key_quote: The 2019 Appropriations Act passed by Congress explicitly rejected President Trump’s $5.7 billion demand for a border wall and forbade construction in certain areas.

input_prompt:
Claim:
The oldest active national emergency is from President Jimmy Carter in 1979, related to the Iran hostage crisis.

Article Title:
Iran hostage crisis - Wikipedia

Google Search Snippet:
The Iran hostage crisis began on November 4, 1979, when 66 Americans, including diplomats and other civilian personnel, were taken hostage at the Embassy of ...

Full Page Content:
Representing the United States abroad has been a dangerous job since the beginning of the Republic, but that was never truer than during the Carter Administration. In the wake of a successful revolution by Islamic fundamentalists against the pro-American Shah of Iran, the United States became an object of virulent criticism and the U.S. Embassy in Tehran was a visible target. On November 4, 1979, Iranian students seized the embassy and detained more than 50 Americans, ranging from the Chargé d’Affaires to the most junior members of the staff, as hostages. The Iranians held the American diplomats hostage for 444 days. While the courage of the American hostages in Tehran and of their families at home reflected the best tradition of the Department of State, the Iran hostage crisis undermined Carter’s conduct of foreign policy. The crisis dominated the headlines and news broadcasts and made the Administration look weak and ineffectual. Although patient diplomacy conducted by Deputy Secretary Warren Christopher eventually resolved the crisis, Carter’s foreign policy team often seemed weak and vacillating.
The Administration’s vitality was sapped, and the Soviet Union took advantage of America’s weakness to win strategic advantage for itself. In 1979, Soviet-supported Marxist rebels made strong gains in Ethiopia, Angola, and Mozambique. Vietnam fought a successful border war with China and took over Cambodia from the murderous Khmer Rouge. And, in late 1979, the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan to support its shaky Marxist government.
In light of these challenges to global stability, President Carter significantly altered his view of both the Soviet Union and the advice of his own advisers. Carter initially favored Secretary Vance’s policy of negotiation, but by 1980 was more receptive to National Security Adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski’s more confrontational stance. Once again the National Security Council and the Department of State were in open conflict. The issue came to a head when Secretary Vance opposed a mission to rescue the hostages in Iran—a move championed by Brzezinski. Vance had been correct—the 1980 mission was a debacle. But Vance was frustrated and he resigned in protest in April 1980. Cyrus Vance was the first Secretary of State clearly and publicly to tie his resignation to a difference of opinion over policy since William Jennings Bryan in 1915. Carter chose Senator Edmund Muskie as his new Secretary.
history@state.gov
Phone: 202-955-0200
Report an issue on this page

Provide relevant evidence.

output.summary: The article discusses the Iran hostage crisis, which began in 1979, and mentions that the crisis significantly impacted President Carter's administration. However, it does not explicitly state that the national emergency declared by Carter in response to the crisis is the oldest active one.

I’ve Lived on the Border My Entire Life. The Courts Must Shut Down Trump’s Border Wall
Trump’s ‘Big, Beautiful’ Wall Crumbles in Court

Provide relevant evidence.

output.summary: The evidence indicates that Trump's declaration of a national emergency to fund the border wall was indeed the first time a president used such powers to fund a policy that Congress had explicitly rejected, as the 2019 Appropriations Act forbade the construction of the wall in certain areas and denied Trump's funding request.
output.key_quote: The 2019 Appropriations Act passed by Congress explicitly rejected President Trump’s $5.7 billion demand for a border wall and forbade construction in certain areas.

input_prompt:
Claim: The oldest active national emergency is from President Jimmy Carter in 1979, related to the Iran hostage crisis.
Category: historical
Extraction confidence: 0.90

Evidence:
UNCLEAR (6 sources):
  1. Executive Order 12170 - National Archives | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/codification/executive-order/12170.html
     Summary: 301. I, JIMMY CARTER, President of the United States, find that the situation in Iran constitutes an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security, ...
  2. Notice of the Continuation of the Iran Emergency | Ronald Reagan | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://www.reaganlibrary.gov/archives/speech/notice-continuation-iran-emergency
     Summary: On November 14, 1979, by Executive Order No. 12170, President Carter declared a national emergency to deal with the threat to the national security, foreign ...
  3. The Iranian Hostage Crisis - Short History | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/short-history/iraniancrises
     Summary: On November 4, 1979, Iranian students seized the embassy and detained more than 50 Americans, ranging from the Chargé d'Affaires to the most junior members of ...
  4. International Emergency Economic Powers Act Message to the ... | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/documents/international-emergency-economic-powers-act-message-the-congress-reporting-administration
     Summary: On November 14, 1979, in Executive Order No. 12170 I declared a national emergency to deal with the threat to the national security, foreign ...
  5. Special report: America's perpetual state of emergency - USA Today | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2014/10/22/president-obama-states-of-emergency/16851775/
     Summary: An emergency declared by President Jimmy Carter on the 10th day of the Iranian hostage crisis in 1979 remains in effect almost 35 years later.
  6. Iran hostage crisis - Wikipedia | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran_hostage_crisis
     Summary: The article discusses the Iran hostage crisis, which began in 1979, and mentions that the crisis significantly impacted President Carter's administration. However, it does not explicitly state that the national emergency declared by Carter in response to the crisis is the oldest active one.

Provide the structured verdict.

output.summary: The evidence indicates that President Jimmy Carter declared a national emergency related to the Iran hostage crisis in 1979, which has been continued by subsequent administrations. However, while several high-reliability sources confirm the declaration and its continuation, there is no explicit consensus on whether it is definitively the oldest active national emergency, as some sources do not address this point directly.
